item.title: Making a program
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“Daginith, post:68, topic:436872”][quote author=ollie123 link=topic=539587.msg3955395#msg3955395 date=1332704135]

here ya go. hello world in brainfuck.

++++++++++[>+++++++>++++++++++>+++>+<<<<-]>++.>+.+++++++..+++.>++.<<+++++++++++++++.>.+++.------.--------.>+.>.

however this prints the same. just no loops used.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++.>+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++.>++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++.>++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++.>+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++.>++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++.>++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++.>+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++.>+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++.>++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++.>++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++.>++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++.>

Now write the guessing game in Brainfuck

that’s impossibru because you can’t generate random (as far as i know) numbers in brainfuck.

but here’s one that prints my name

++++++++++[>+++++++++++>+++++++++>+++++++++++>++++++++++>+++++++++++>++++++++++>+++++++++<<<<<<<-]>.>+++++++.>++++++.>+++++.>++++++++.>+.>++++.
[/quote]i’m sure you could implement a pseudorandom generator somehow

At first i thought this was a troll, then looked it up:
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brainfuck
people never cease to amuse me.

Not as bad as LOLCode

…LOLCode? Time for google![/quote]
It’s not as much of a mindfuck as brainfuck is, but LOLcode is like listening to a one year old talk, or watching one type. It makes no sense.

Read full topic

[/quote]i’m sure you could implement a pseudorandom generator somehow

At first i thought this was a troll, then looked it up:

en.wikipedia.org

Brainfuck

Brainfuck is an esoteric programming language created in 1993 by Urban Müller, and notable for its extreme minimalism. The language consists of only eight simple commands and an instruction pointer. While it is fully Turing-complete, it is not intended for practical use, but to challenge and amuse programmers. Brainfuck simply requires one to break commands into microscopic steps. The language's name is a reference to the slang term brainfuck, which refers to things so complicated or unusual that...


people never cease to amuse me.[/quote]

Not as bad as LOLCode

Read full topic

item.title: Making a program
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

I just started learning Python yesterday. Did another quadratic formula calculator, this time in Python.

Give suggestions, comments, etc.

# ########################### #
# Quadratic Formula Calculator
# by Whac
#
#
# Now in Python!
# March 24, 2012
# ########################### #

import string;
import random;
import sys;
import math;

print """
============================
Quadratic Formula Calculator
============================

Enter a, b, and c for the equation:
ax^2 + bx + c = 0

""";

try:
	# parts make it simpler to understand vs
	# it being done in one line, etc.
	a = float(raw_input("A: "));
	b = float(raw_input("B: "));
	c = float(raw_input("C: "));
	
	part1 = (-1 * b);
	part2 = math.sqrt(math.pow(b, 2) - (4 * a * c));
	part3 = 2 * a;
	
	x1 = (part1 + part2) / part3;
	x2 = (part1 - part2) / part3;
	
	print "X can be " + str(x1) + " or " + str(x2) + "\n";
except NameError:
	print "Invalid input. Please try again.\n";
except ValueError:
	print "Invalid input. Please try again.\n";

Read full topic

item.title: Making a program
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“ollie123, post:55, topic:436872”][quote author=_s link=topic=539587.msg3953770#msg3953770 date=1332545792]

Here’s a random ‘number guessing game’ i made in python a while back. Very simple:

[code=python]#python number game by Daginith
import random #to generate a random number

true = 1
false = 2
start = true #keeps user in a loop
number = random.randint(1,10) #generates random number 1-10
guess = 0 #the number of guesses the user has left

print “Welcome to Daginith’s Number guessing game!”
print “You have 5 guesses to guess the number!”

while start == true: #starts loop
userin = input("Guess a number 1-10: ") #stores input
if userin == number: #if correct
print “correct!”
start = false #ends loop
elif guess == 5: #if all guesses used
print “You used up all your guesses!”
print “The random number was”, number
elif userin != number: #if wrong
left = 5 - guess #shows remaining guesses
print “WRONG!”
print “You have”, left
print “guesses left!”
guess = guess + 1 #adds one to the guess count

    [/code]

[/quote]Scheme equivalent for your education:

(define (guessgame) (let loop ((tries 5) (number (random 10))) ; RANDOM isn't standard!! (if (zero? tries) (begin (display "You used up all your guesses!") (newline) (display (string-append "The random number was " (number->string number))) (newline)) (begin (display "Guess a number 1-10: ") (if (= (read) number) (begin (display "correct!") (newline)) (begin (display "WRONG!") (newline) (display (string-append "You have " (number->string (- tries 1)) " guesses left!")) (newline) (loop (- tries 1) number))))))) (guessgame)

Can you do one in Haskell?[/quote]sure

[code=haskell]import System.Random

guessgame :: IO ()
guessgame = do
number <- randomRIO (0, 10)
loop 5 (number :: Int)
where
loop 0 number = do
putStrLn “You used up all your guesses!”
putStrLn $ "The random number was " ++ show number
loop tries number = do
putStr "Guess a number 1-10: "
guessnum <- getLine
if (read guessnum :: Int) == number
then putStrLn “correct!”
else do
putStrLn “WRONG!”
putStrLn $ “You have " ++ show (tries - 1) ++ " guesses left!”
loop (tries - 1) number

main = guessgame[/code]
unfortunately the amount of IO (which Haskell pushes into the IO monad) in this program make this quite ugly.

Read full topic

item.title: Making a program
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

[quote="_s, post:54, topic:436872"][quote author=Daginith link=topic=539587.msg3953730#msg3953730 date=1332542082]
Here’s a random ‘number guessing game’ i made in python a while back. Very simple:

[code=python]#python number game by Daginith
import random #to generate a random number

true = 1
false = 2
start = true #keeps user in a loop
number = random.randint(1,10) #generates random number 1-10
guess = 0 #the number of guesses the user has left

print “Welcome to Daginith’s Number guessing game!”
print “You have 5 guesses to guess the number!”

while start == true: #starts loop
userin = input("Guess a number 1-10: ") #stores input
if userin == number: #if correct
print “correct!”
start = false #ends loop
elif guess == 5: #if all guesses used
print “You used up all your guesses!”
print “The random number was”, number
elif userin != number: #if wrong
left = 5 - guess #shows remaining guesses
print “WRONG!”
print “You have”, left
print “guesses left!”
guess = guess + 1 #adds one to the guess count

    [/code]

[/quote]Scheme equivalent for your education:

(define (guessgame) (let loop ((tries 5) (number (random 10))) ; RANDOM isn't standard!! (if (zero? tries) (begin (display "You used up all your guesses!") (newline) (display (string-append "The random number was " (number->string number))) (newline)) (begin (display "Guess a number 1-10: ") (if (= (read) number) (begin (display "correct!") (newline)) (begin (display "WRONG!") (newline) (display (string-append "You have " (number->string (- tries 1)) " guesses left!")) (newline) (loop (- tries 1) number))))))) (guessgame)[/quote]

Can you do one in Haskell?

item.title: Making a program
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“austinsobes, post:45, topic:436872”]I never said I was a White-Hat hacker. I said that I partook in White-Hat activities. And I never said that you aren’t a great programmer unless you’ve stopped learning. I also never said I was the fastest C++ coder ever either, I simply said I was able to program fast because of how easy it is for me to process things. Also, LISP looks gross. Don’t give a fuck about learning it for that reason only. Am I stupid because of that? probably. But one language probably won’t matter. Considering that a good majority of programming jobs are using C#, C++, Java, Python, and Ruby. And even apart from that, I planned to start my own ‘company’ I guess you could call it. Business and shit isn’t my thing just yet. But I plan to write software and probably get into gaming very soon.

It’s irrelevant, but after I learned how to communicate at the lowest level. I plan to write a small graphic OS. If that is a successful project I planned to try to make my own gaming console. And then if that basic console was a success I’d keep remaking newer and better versions until I created my own gaming console that would match up to say, a gamecube or a classic xbox(Of course without hundreds of games and companies to produce). I’ve got dreams and I’m very dedicated to them.[/quote]
your literal interpretation of my silly hyperbole aside,

I wouldn't say great because I'm not finished learning.
implies somewhat that 'finishing learning' would be a clause for achievement of being a great programmer and that all great programmers would have had to have finished learning :p

Lisp looks gross to the untrained eye, but code in general looks gross to the untrained eye. to appreciate the beauty of code you must be able to understand it, and likewise to appreciate Lisp you must allow the same liberty. the stance you take on programming languages is fine if you want to remain stuck using imperative languages for your whole life (and there’s very little to learn from imperative programming since imperativeness is natural to us anyway), but Lisp allows you to program functionally which is a good idea if you want to understand and create alternative (read: sometimes better) solutions to problems. (disclaimer: Lisp can be extended to support pretty much any other paradigm too. see: CLOS, various Prolog-in-lisp implementations).

for companies and on the topic of Lisp, may i suggest some of Paul Graham’s ‘essays’, notably http://www.paulgraham.com/avg.html. please read this!! it’s cool that you want to make a startup (who doesn’t nowadays), but you have to be realistic with dreams. making something like the XBox or GameCube entirely on your own will be very very very difficult.

[quote=“t4, post:44, topic:436872”]it’ll compile and execute, but it’s poor style(?) and providing it as an example implies you want others to learn from it - meaning they’d learn wrong.[/quote]if out-of-date style counts as poor style then yes.

[quote=“Newty, post:47, topic:436872”]I just remembered something… _s is fucking awesome[/quote]is it bad that i sigged this

[quote=“sinisoul, post:49, topic:436872”]I’m racist towards procedural paradigms[/quote]??? is this another one of your ‘barely related, but maybe i will look smart’ musings that no one gets/cares about

Read full topic
